background: Maternal stress and depression during pregnancy and infancy are associated with adverse child health outcomes and altered DNA methylation, but the biological mechanisms are unclear.
hypotheses: Prenatal stress and depression are associated with differences in newborn cord blood mononuclear cell DNA methylation.
Postnatal stress and depression are associated with differences in infant peripheral blood mononuclear cell DNA methylation at 12 months of age.
The cumulative effect of prenatal and postnatal adversity influences infant DNA methylation.
major_findings: Prenatal stress was associated with differential DNA methylation at 8 CpG sites in newborns, and prenatal depression at 2 CpG sites.
Postnatal stress was associated with differential DNA methylation at 8 CpG sites in 12-month-olds, and postnatal depression at 11 CpG sites.

Composite prenatal and postnatal adversity scores identified additional CpG sites associated with differential DNA methylation, suggesting a cumulative effect of maternal mental health on the infant epigenome.
Several associated genes (PLAGL1, HYMAI, BRD2, and ERC2) have been implicated in adverse fetal outcomes and neuropsychiatric disorders.
